description: From Middle English path, peth, from Old English p√¶√æ (‚Äúpath, track‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *pa√æ, from Proto-Germanic *pa√æaz (‚Äúpath‚Äù) (compare West Frisian paad, Dutch pad, German Pfad), Ancient Greek œÄŒ±œÑŒ≠œâ (pat√©≈ç) / œÄŒ¨œÑŒøœÇ (p√°tos), from Iranian (compare Avestan ê¨ûê¨Äê¨•ê¨ôê¨Ä‚Äé (panta, ‚Äúway‚Äù), ê¨ûê¨Äê¨öê¨Ä‚Äé (paŒ∏a, genitive), Old Persian [script needed] (pathi-)), from Proto-Iranian *p√°ntaHh, from Proto-Indo-Iranian *p√°ntaHs (compare Sanskrit ‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§æ (p√°nthƒÅ-)), from Proto-Indo-European *p√≥ntoh‚ÇÅs, from *pent- (‚Äúpath‚Äù) (compare English find). Doublet of panth.

entries.meaning: A trail for the use of, or worn by, pedestrians.

examples: the path of a meteor, of a caravan, or of a storm

entries.meaning: (paganism) A Pagan tradition, for example witchcraft, Wicca, druidism, Heathenry.
A metaphorical course or route; progress.
examples: As I explored the possibility of a library science path, having previously been employed in libraries during my school career and afterwards, I decided that I needed to actually experience work in a library setting full time again  [‚Ä¶]

entries.meaning: A method or direction of proceeding.
examples: The paths of glory lead but to the grave.

entries.meaning: (computing) A human-readable specification for a location within a hierarchical or tree-like structure, such as a file system or as part of a URL.
examples: Use the network path \\Marketing\Files to find the documents you need.

entries.meaning: (graph theory) A sequence of vertices from one vertex to another using the arcs (edges). A path does not visit the same vertex more than once (unless it is a closed path, where only the first and the last vertex are the same).

(topology) A continuous map 
  
    
      
        f
      
    
    {\displaystyle f}
  
 from the unit interval 
  
    
      
        I
        =
        [
        0
        ,
        1
        ]
      
    
    {\displaystyle I=[0,1]}
  
 to a topological space 
  
    
      
        X
      
    
    {\displaystyle X}
  
.
(rail transport) A slot available for allocation to a railway train over a given route in between other trains.

verbs.description: path (third-person singular simple present paths, present participle pathing, simple past and past participle pathed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make a path in, or on (something), or for (someone).
(computing, intransitive) To navigate through a file system directory tree (to a desired file or folder).
examples: Next, you need to path to the location of the executable and run it from there.
